arm_group.description: Patients who's peroperative BMI is less than the 10th centile
Patients who's peroperative BMI equals or is greater than the 10th centile

brief_summary.textblock:
Esophagectomy for cancer is often accompanied with severe preoperative weight loss. Body
      Mass Index (BMI) values are age-independent and the same for both sexes. From the
      perspective that these two parameters should actually be taken into account too, we
      developed a model to calculate "age-gender specific BMI-percentiles" (AG-BMI) and tested
      this model in relation to survival outcome after esophagectomy for cancer.

clinical_study.brief_title: Age and Gender Corrected Body Mass Index

detailed_description.textblock:
Age-Gender specific BMI percentiles are more accurate compared to the current BMI classes in
      predicting Overall Survival (OS) after esophagectomy for cancer. Furthermore we believe in a
      more devastating impact on OS from underweight and not from overweight.

      By preoperatively identifying risk patients for poorer OS, especially the non-tumoral
      deaths, this can be a tool to tailor postoperative nutritional strategies to counter further
      weight loss and bringing postoperative weight to normal ranges.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  any type of esophagectomy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Preoperative organ metastasis (cM+ or yM+)

          -  esophageal bypass surgery

study_pop.textblock: Esophageal cancer patients recieving an esophagectomy

facility.name: Univresity Hospital Leuven - dept. Thoracic Surgery

clinical_study.official_title: Age and Gender Corrected Body Mass Index: When Preoperative Weight Loss and Underweight Are Becomming Clinically Significant in Esophagectomy for Cancer.

oversight_info.authority: Belgium: Federal Agency for Medicines and Health Products, FAMHP

primary_outcome.description: Overall 5-year survival after esophagectomy for cancer

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
